ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Close-to-Reality Sliding-Corrosion Test-Rig for Oilfield Application
Übertragbarkeit des Gleitkorrosionsprüfstandes auf die Ölfeldanwendungen

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Sliding-corrosion phenomena play a crucial role in reducing the lifetime of tubings in the oil production industry. The aim of the present work is to develop and apply a close-to-reality test rig to describe the tribological performance of low-alloyed Carbon-steel (C-steel) under sliding-corrosion conditions in O2-free environment. The proposed test rig is highly relevant for the oil production industry and has been designed at the Austrian Competence Center for Tribology (AC²T). The benefit of this equipment is that it allows the setting of the CO2 atmosphere at a certain partial pressure while simultaneously varying the pH-value, Cl− ion concentration, and temperature of the electrolyte solution. Pure corrosion phenomena are investigated within a designed coupon box where conditions of steam, electrolyte injection, static, and dynamic flow are controlled. In addition to the corrosive environment, a tribological reciprocating sliding contact is implemented between tubing segments and coupling samples. Within this study, a commercially available low-alloyed C-steel was selected as base material for the tubing, which was tribologically stressed under reciprocating sliding contact against spray metal coated couplings. The results show a high influence of the steel microstructure on the performance of low-alloyed C-steel tubings under sliding-corrosion. Additionally, the dominant damage mechanisms that are observed in real field applications could be successfully reproduced by experimental simulation using this newly designed close-to-reality test rig.

Abstract.Heading: Zusammenfassung
Abstract.Para: In der Ölfeldindustrie bewirken die Gleitkorrosionsmechanismen eine Verringerung der Lebensdauer der Steigrohre bei Bohrlöchern. Das Ziel dieser Arbeit ist es, das Tribokorrosionsverhalten von niederlegierten Kohlenstoffstählen (C-Stähle) in sauerstofffreier Umgebung mit dem Gleitkorrosionsprüfstand zu beschreiben. Der nachstehende Teststand hat eine sehr hohe Wichtigkeit für die Ölindustrie und wurde am Österreichischen Kompetenzzentrum für Tribologie (AC²T research GmbH) entwickelt. Der Vorteil dieses Teststandes ist es, einen Überdruck der CO2 Atmosphäre realisieren zu können und zusätzlich unterschiedliche Parameter wie pH-Werte, Cl Ionenkonzentration, usw. zu messen. Einflüsse auf die Korrosion wie zum Beispiel Flüssigkeitsbewegung, Dampfkorrosion, usw. können in einer Korrosionsteststandzelle kontrolliert eingestellt und bestimmt werden. In der Gleitkorrosionsteststandzelle werden zusätzlich zu den korrosiven Bedingungen ein Gleitkontakt zwischen Muffe und Steigrohr realisiert. Die Ergebnisse zeigen einen hohen Einfluss der Gefügestruktur auf das Verhalten und Lebensdauer der Steigrohre unter Gleitkorrosion. Die dominanten Schädigungsmechanismen im Ölfeld konnten mit dem entwickelten Gleitkorrosionsprüfstand gut nachgebildet werden und stellen dabei nicht nur einen wirtschaftlichen Vorteil für Unternehmenspartner dar, sondern bilden auch eine wichtige Wissensbasis für weitere Aktivitäten auf dem Gebiet der Gleitkorrosion.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In the oil production, wear occurs at the contact interface between the coupling and the tubing (Fig. 1). In addition to mechanical wear, corrosion plays a crucial role within the operation of the crude oil pumps. The carbon steel typically used under these conditions exhibits a significant corrosion and wear.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Oil field application: a) horse head pump, b) tubing, c) coupling

Section1.Para: Sliding-corrosion occurs between the coupling and the tubing under operation conditions. It is a combination of mechanical wear and chemical attack. The lifetime of the tubing is limited by different damaging mechanisms, such as local damage of the sliding/corrosive top coating due to the impact and sliding of the coupling and corrosion due to sweet gas (CO2). Due to corrosive attack, an iron carbonate layer (siderite – FeCO3) is formed, which decreases the corrosion rate [1–3].

The aim of this work is to construct and realise a model test rig, to characterise and to compare the tribological mechanisms and the corrosion attack of a standard C-steel for the oilfield application. An increase in lifetime of the tubing steel in addition to gaining the fundamental expertise on this topic will be beneficial for both the partners and for the science of “sliding-corrosion” at AC²T.

Section2.Heading: Sliding/Corrosion Tests
Section2.Para: A novel test rig has been established for close-to-reality sliding/corrosion testing. One major advantage of this equipment is that the CO2 atmosphere can be adjusted at a certain partial pressure, also pH-value, Clˉ ion concentration and the temperature can be varied, respectively. In addition to the corrosive atmosphere, a tribological oscillation sliding contact is realised on the carbon steel tubing segments against Ni-based hardfaced coupling samples. The sliding/corrosion test rig is illustrated in Fig. 2.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Sliding/corrosion test rig: a) photograph of the whole test rig, b) schematic working principle

Section2.Para: The testing samples (three tubing and three coupling segments) are installed in a vessel which is filled with aqueous saline medium. In addition to the corrosive atmosphere, a tribological reciprocating sliding contact is realised where low-alloyed C-steel tubing is rubbed against the spray metal coating. The linear oscillation sliding contact takes place between three segments of low-alloyed C-steel tubing and three segments of spray metal coating.

The other main components are a circulation pump providing the necessary flow through the test cell, external water heating with a heat exchanger to control the temperature, a gas feeding unit, and a coupon box for mass loss measurements.

During the testing procedure, several parameters, like conductivity of the aqueous medium, friction coefficient, and pH-value, are monitored online together with temperature, oxygen content, and CO2 partial pressure.

To study the influence of corrosion in detail, three types of experiments are defined. In the first variant, the “sliding corrosion test” (SC-test), both mechanical wear and chemical corrosion occur simultaneously. During this test, a second set of tubing samples is placed in a coupon box for pure “corrosion tests” (C-test), the second variant. The fluid chemistry and flow conditions are compared to the SC-tests. Accelerated corrosion occurs due to saline water and high pressure of CO2. The third variant, the “sliding test” (S-test), allows the testing of pure mechanical wear. Corrosion is minimised due to the presence of distilled water and inert gas N2, which replace the brine solution and the CO2, respectively.
Within the tests performed in this study, the following parameters were kept constant (for SC-tests summarised in Table 1). The normal load was adjusted to reproduce real field conditions.

Section2.Heading: Investigated Materials
Section2.Para: Double normalised carbon steel was used as tubing material. The chemical composition is given in Table 2. The tubing exhibits a ferritic/pearlitic (f/p) microstructure stretched in pipe direction due to the manufacturing procedure. The hardness of the ferritic/pearlitic microstructure was ~ 205 HV1. For the coupling counterpart material, a standard Ni-based hardfacing was used with a thickness of 0.5 mm and a hardness of ~ 750 HV1. The detailed specification of coupling properties is described in detail elsewhere [4].

Out of the delivered tubing and coupling parts, three sample segments are produced (see Fig. 3). The pipe segments are cut to a length of 550 mm, whereas couplings are not cut in length. The tubing samples are pickled to remove the oxide layer present from the production process, whereas the spray metal coated coupling was used in the tests in the as-received condition. The tubing surface has a Ra roughness value of ~ 3.9 µm. The grinded surface of the coupling has a Ra roughness value of ~ 0.24 µm.

Section2.Heading: Contact Simulation
Section2.Para: The contact mechanics simulation using finite elements shows the stresses in and outside the contact area of the coupling/tubing contact. The models are simplified (without roughness and fluids). A 2D and a 3D model with and without friction were used. Figure 4 shows the comparison of the Mises stress and the model.

The maximum Mises stress of ~ 18.5 MPa is below the surface at a depth of ~ 35 µm. The differences of Mises stress between tubing and coupling are due to the different elastic modulus between steel and nickel. The Mises stress without and with slip from the 3D-model is shown in Fig. 5.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Comparison Mises stress with slip in dependence of friction coefficient

Section2.Para: When the friction coefficient increases, the maximum Mises stress is higher and closer to the surface. This enables the crack initiation directly below the surface, and the corrosive electrolyte can penetrate in the material.

Section2.Heading: Sliding/Corrosion Behaviour
Section2.Para: The tribological wear behaviour was investigated comparing three coupling samples sliding under reciprocating sliding against low-alloyed C-steel tubing segments. The testing conditions were kept constant (see details in Table 1). Several testing parameters were monitored and recorded during the test. A typical testing plot is shown in Fig. 6.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Typical testing plot of a SC-test showing all parameters recorded online

Section2.Para: The wear mechanisms in the presence of brine of double normalised ferritic/pearlitic tubing sliding against Ni-based coated coupling is shown in Fig. 7. Under stereo microscopy, the microstructure shows bright (sliding contact) and dark (corrosion attack) regions within the wear scar (Fig. 7a). The sliding area contains cracks which appeared due to the simultaneous action of contact stresses and corrosion (Fig. 7c). Localised corrosion can be observed within the banded structure of ferrite/pearlite. The observed localised corrosion at the grain boundaries can lead to cracks initiating and propagating underneath the contact surface. These cracks may ultimately result in grain pull out (Fig. 7b and 7d).

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: Based on the present investigations on CO2 sliding/corrosion phenomena, the following main conclusions are drawn:

ItemContent.Para: The novel close-to-reality test rig was able to reproduce the conditions occurring on real tubing strings under real oilfield applications.

The predominant wear mechanisms under sliding/corrosion conditions are a combination of mechanical damage with localised corrosive attack. Sliding wear and corrosion attack in the bended ferritic/pearlitic microstructure occur simultanously. Hence, corrosion below the sliding surface was observed.
CO2 corrosion exacerbates wear by delaminating and extending sub-surface cracks for ferritic/pearlitic steels.

Section1.Para: In summary, the dominant damage mechanisms observed in the laboratory tests correspond to those observed under real field applications. Therefore, this work can be seen as a basis for further studies with the aim of selecting improved microstructures, heat treatment procedures, and corrosion inhibitor products with the global goal to decrease operational expenditures in the oil industry.
